entries.name: Spell Slots
entries: Any spell slots you gain from the Spellcasting feature are converted to sorcery points. Once you have added together your levels as prescribed in the Spell Slots section, take the resulting total and refer to the Sorcerer table for that level to determine the amount of sorcery points you have. For example, a character with 3 sorcerer levels and 2 paladin levels counts as a 4th-level sorcerer for the purposes of determining that character's total sorcery points.

foundryClassFeature.name: Metamagic
entries: Also at 2nd level, your growing ability to harness sorcerous magic allows you to alter the ways that your spells manifest. Choose two of the following metamagic options. You gain one additional option of your choice at 6th level, 10th level, 14th level and 18th level. When you gain a new metamagic option, you can also replace one of your current metamagic options with another one, if you choose.
You can use only one Metamagic option on a spell when you cast it, unless the Metamagic specifies otherwise.

classFeature.name: Sorcerous Origin
entries: Choose a sorcerous origin, which describes the source of your innate magical power, such as Draconic Bloodline.
Your choice grants you features at 1st level and again at 6th, 14th, and 18th level.

classFeature.name: Spell Versatility
entries: {@i 1st-level sorcerer feature (enhances Spellcasting)}

{@note Note that this feature is intended for use with the original Sorcerer class presented in the Player's Handbook. It is presented here for convenience, and may be unsuitable for use as a Variant Sorcerer feature.}

Whenever you finish a long rest, you can replace one spell you learned from this Spellcasting feature with another spell from the sorcerer spell list. The new spell must be the same level as the spell you replace.

classFeature.name: Sorcery
entries: An event in your past, or in the life of a parent or ancestor, left an indelible mark on you, infusing you with arcane magic. This magic, whatever its origin, fuels your spells.

entries.name: Cantrips
entries: At 1st level, you know four cantrips of your choice from the {@filter sorcerer spell list|spells|level=0|class=Variant Sorcerer (VS)}. You learn more sorcerer cantrips of your choice at higher levels, as shown in the Cantrips Known column of the sorcerer table.

entries.name: Spells Known of 1st Level and Higher
entries: You know two 1st-level spells of your choice from the sorcerer spell list. The Spells Known column of the sorcerer table shows when you learn more sorcerer spells of your choice, which can be of a level no greater than the number shown in the Sorcery Limit column for your sorcerer level. The spells you choose also can't exceed 5th level.

Each time you finish a long rest, you can choose one of the sorcerer spells you know and replace it with another spell from the sorcerer spell list, which also must be of a level no higher than your Sorcery Limit, and can't exceed 5th level.

entries.name: Using Sorcery to Create Spell Slots
entries: You have 4 sorcery points, which increase as shown in the Sorcery Points column of the sorcerer table along with your sorcerer level. You can have no more sorcery points than the amount shown on the sorcerer table for your sorcerer level. You regain spent sorcery points when you finish a long rest.

Whenever you require a spell slot, such as when casting a spell, you must expend sorcery points from your pool to create a spell slot, then use that slot as needed. The amount of points you must spend equals 1 + the spell's level when you cast it, and the highest level spell slot you can create is equal to your Sorcery Limit. Even though you might have enough points to create a slot above this level, you can't do so using sorcery.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Charisma is your spellcasting ability for your sorcerer spells, since the power of your magic relies on your ability to project your will into the world. You use your Charisma whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Charisma modifier when setting the saving throw DC for a sorcerer spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus
entries: You can use an {@item arcane focus|PHB} as a spellcasting focus for your sorcerer spells.

classFeature.name: Spell Conduit
entries: At 2nd level, you can quickly call forth magical energy or surge excess power into your spells. When you cast a spell, you can use one of the following methods to amplify the spell's effects for that casting.

entries.name: Quick Cast
entries: You can cast a spell with a casting time of 1 action as a bonus action. You can't cast another spell with a casting time of 1 action during this turn, unless that spell is a cantrip.

entries.name: Twin Cast
entries: When you cast a spell that targets only one creature and doesn't have a range of self, you can target a second creature in range with the same spell. In order to be eligible for this method, a spell must be incapable of targeting more than one creature at the spell's current level. For example, {@spell magic missile} isn't eligible, but {@spell ray of frost} is.
You have a number of uses of this feature equal to your proficiency bonus, and any expended uses are replenished when you finish a long rest.

classFeature.name: Metamagic
entries: Also at 2nd level, your growing ability to harness sorcerous magic allows you to alter the ways that your spells manifest. Choose two of the following metamagic options. You gain one additional option of your choice at 6th level, 10th level, 14th level and 18th level. When you gain a new metamagic option, you can also replace one of your current metamagic options with another one, if you choose.
You can use only one Metamagic option on a spell when you cast it, unless the Metamagic specifies otherwise.

entries.name: Anchored Spell
entries: When you cast a spell that requires concentration, you can spend 2 sorcery points to cause the spell to last until the end of your next turn, without requiring concentration, even after the spell would normally end.
You can only use this metamagic option once for each casting of a spell.

entries.name: Careful Spell
entries: When you cast a spell that forces other creatures to make a saving throw, you can protect some of those creatures from the spell's full force. To do so, you spend 1 sorcery point and choose a number of those creatures up to your Charisma modifier (minimum of one creature). A chosen creature automatically succeeds on its saving throw against the spell.

entries.name: Distant Spell
entries: When you cast a spell that has a range of 5 feet or greater, you can expend 1 sorcery point to double the range of the spell.
When you cast a spell that has a range of touch, you can expend 1 sorcery point to make the range of the spell 30 feet.

entries.name: Empowered Spell
entries: When you roll damage for a spell, or when you roll a pool of dice for a spell (such as with the sleep spell), you can spend 1 sorcery point to reroll a number of the damage or pooled dice up to your Charisma modifier (minimum of one). You must use the new rolls.
You can use Empowered Spell even if you have already used a different metamagic option during the casting of the spell.

entries.name: Extended Spell
entries: When you cast a spell that has a duration of 1 minute or longer, you can spend 2 sorcery points to double its duration, to a maximum duration of 24 hours.

entries.name: Fortifying Spell
entries: When you cast a spell of 1st level or higher, you can spend sorcery points equal to the spell's level to roll the same number of {@scaledice 1d4|1-9|d4}s and gain temporary hit points equal to the total amount rolled.

entries.name: Heightened Spell
entries: When a spell of yours requires one or more targets to make a saving throw to resist the spell's effects, you can use your reaction and expend 3 sorcery points to give one target of the spell disadvantage on its saving throw.

entries.name: Homing Spell
entries: When you make a ranged attack roll for a spell you cast, you can spend 2 sorcery points to reroll the attack once and use the second result. You can use this metamagic after the attack roll, but before the DM determines whether the attack hits.
You can use Homing Spell even if you have already used a different metamagic option during the casting of the spell.

entries.name: Lashing Spell
entries: When you cast a spell that has an area of effect and a duration of instantaneous, you can spend 2 sorcery points to create a whirl containing the spell's effect. When you do, the spell's area remains until the end of your next turn, affecting each creature who enters the area for the first time on a turn or ends its turn within the area.

entries.name: Miring Spell
entries: When you cast a spell with an area of effect, you can expend 2 sorcery points to create a lingering field of force. The spell's area of effect becomes difficult terrain until the start of your next turn.

entries.name: Persistent Spell
entries: When a spell ends before its full duration has elapsed, you can use your reaction and spend sorcery points equal to 1 + half the spell's level (rounded down) to choose a different target for the spell instead of ending it. The target you choose must be one that you can see, one suitable to the spell and within 30 feet of the original target.

entries.name: Prismatic Spell
entries: When you cast a spell that deals acid, cold, fire, lightning, or poison damage, you can spend 1 sorcery point to change one such damage type to another from the same list.

entries.name: Subtle Spell
entries: When you cast a spell thatrequires somatic or verbal components, you can spend 2 sorcery points to forgo those components for this casting.
You can use Subtle Spell even if you have already used a different metamagic option during the casting of the spell.

classFeature.name: Ensorceled Cantrip
entries: At 10th level, you have learned to apply your sorcerous manipulation of magic to simple spells. Each time you cast a cantrip, you can apply one metamagic option you know to that cantrip without paying the metamagic's sorcery point cost.

classFeature.name: Sorcerous Restoration
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you regain expended sorcery points equal to half your sorcerer level whenever you finish a short rest.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Sorcerous Versatility
entries: {@i 4th-level sorcerer {@variantrule optional class features|tce|optional feature}}
Whenever you reach a level in this class that grants the Ability Score Improvement feature, you can do one of the following, representing the magic within you flowing in new ways:

items: Replace one of the options you chose for the Metamagic feature with a different Metamagic option available to you.
Replace one cantrip you learned from this class's Spellcasting feature with another cantrip from the {@filter sorcerer spell list|spells|level=0|class=Variant Sorcerer (VS)}.

classFeature.name: Proficiency Versatility
entries: {@i 4th-level feature (enhances Ability Score Improvement)}

When you gain the Ability Score Improvement feature from your class, you can also replace one of your skill proficiencies with a skill proficiency offered by your class at 1st level (the proficiency you replace needn't be from the class).
This change represents one of your skills atrophying as you focus on a different skill.

classFeature.name: Sorcerous Origin feature
entries: At 6th level, you gain a feature granted by your Sorcerous Origin.

entries: When you reach 8th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

entries: {@i 8th-level feature (enhances Ability Score Improvement)}

This change represents one of your skills atrophying as you focus on a different skill.

classFeature.name: Magical Locus (6th level)
entries: At 11th level, you become able to draw out massive swaths of magical energy and form it into dazzling spells. You can cast one {@filter 6th-level spell of your choice from the sorcerer spell list|spells|class=Variant Sorcerer (VS)|level=6} without expending a spell slot, and you must finish a long rest before you can do so again.
If the spell's level is below your Sorcery Limit when you cast it, you can spend sorcery points to increase the spell's level by the amount of sorcery points spent, up to your Sorcery Limit.

At higher levels, you can cast additional sorcerer spells in this way: one 7th-level spell at 13th level, one 8th-level spell at 15th level, and one 9th-level spell at 17th level. You regain all expended uses of this feature when you finish a long rest.

classFeature.name: Geyser of Magic
entries: At 20th level, the magic flowing from within you is so plentiful that your spell manipulation becomes effortless. You gain the following benefits:

items: You regain expended uses of your Spell Conduit feature when you finish a short rest.
You can use two Metamagic options on a spell when you cast it.
The sorcery point cost for each of your metamagic options decreases by 1, to a minimum of 0.

subclassFeature.name: Sorcerous Origins
entries: The arcane magic you command is infused with elemental air. You learn the following spells at the sorcerer levels listed. These spells count as sorcerer spells for you, and they do not count against your number of spells known.

* Unless you gain this spell from another source, you can summon only {@creature smoke mephit||smoke mephits}, {@creature steam mephit||steam mephits}, {@creature ice mephit||ice mephits}, or {@creature dust mephit||dust mephits} with it.
** Unless you gain this spell from another source, you can summon only {@creature air elemental||air elementals} with it.

subclassFeature.name: Storm Sorcery
entries: Your innate magic comes from the power of elemental air. Many with this power can trace their magic back to a near-death experience caused by the Great Rain, but perhaps you were born during a howling gale so powerful that folk still tell stories of it, or your lineage might include the influence of potent air creatures such as djinn. Whatever the case, the magic of the storm permeates your being.

Storm sorcerers are invaluable members of a ship's crew. Their magic allows them to exert control over wind and weather in their immediate area. Their abilities also prove useful in repelling attacks by sahuagin, pirates, and other waterborne threats.

subclassFeature.name: Tempestuous Magic
entries: Starting at 1st level, you can cause whirling gusts of elemental air to briefly surround you immediately before or after you cast a spell of 1st level or higher, pushing you up to 10 feet in a direction of your choice.

subclassFeature.name: Storm Guide
entries: At 6th level, you gain the ability to subtly control the weather around you.

You can use your bonus action to start or stop manipulating rain. If it is raining, you can cause the rain to stop falling in a 20- foot-radius sphere centered on you as part of this bonus action. If it isn't raining, you can instead expend 2 sorcery points to cause lightrain, which lightly obscures the area, to begin falling in a 100-foot-radius sphere centered on you for up to 1 hour or until you use your bonus action to end this effect.

You can also use your bonus action to start or stop manipulating wind. If it is windy, you can use a bonus action each round to choose the direction that the wind blows in a 100-foot-radius sphere centered on you. The wind blows in that direction until the end of your next turn. This feature doesn't alterthe speed of the wind. If it isn't windy, you can instead expend 2 sorcery points to cause wind to blow at a rate of 20 miles per hour in a vortex filling a 100-foot sphere centered on you, which lasts for up to 1 hour or until you use your bonus action to end this effect.

subclassFeature.name: Astral-bound Soul
entries: Your innate magic is channeled through the planar pools which connect many of the planes of existence to the astral plane. Your soul has been split in two, with the majority of its essence - the "anchor"-bound to the astral plane. Many such souls never awaken their power, but through intense training, a near-death experience, or other elevating event, you have gained awareness and control of this flexible magic source.

subclassFeature.name: Origin Spells
entries: Your magic allows you to connect space, even in others' minds and across planar boundaries. You learn the following spells at the sorcerer levels listed. These spells count as sorcerer spells for you, and they do not count against your number of spells known.

subclassFeature.name: Astral Anchor
entries: Starting when you awaken to this origin at 1st level, you gain control of the astral magic channeled through your soul anchor.

A silvery cord extends from between your shoulder blades and trails behind you, fading to invisibility after 1 foot. This cord is your tether to your astral anchor. Should you travel to the astral plane, such as by the {@spell astral projection} spell, this cord exists in addition to the astral tether to your body. If the cord is cut - something that can happen only when an effect specifically states that it does - your soul and anchor are separated, and your astral-bound soul features are lost. A {@spell greater restoration} or wish spell can restore the link to your soul anchor.

As a bonus action, you can channel magical energy through your astral anchor. For the next minute, when you cast a spell, you can create an invisible, protective field of psychic energy around yourself. This field grants you temporary hit points equal to the spell's level (1 if the spell is a cantrip) + your Charisma modifier, which are lost if they remain when this feature's duration elapses. You have resistance to psychic damage while you have any of these temporary hit points.
Once you have used this feature, you must finish a long rest before you can use it again.

subclassFeature.name: Dire Retreat
entries: Also at 1st level, your soul retreats into your anchor when you are slain, and its magic preserves your body.

While you are tethered to your astral anchor, whenever you die, your body gains the effects of the {@spell gentle repose} spell, and your soul becomes contained within your astral anchor. Any attempt to dispel {@spell gentle repose} cast in this way, or to call your soul away from your astral anchor, fails unless you choose to be affected or the source of the attempt succeeds a Charisma check against your spell save DC.

subclassFeature.name: Siphon Sorcery
entries: Starting at 6th level, you can draw upon your anchor's well of sorcerous power in addition to your own. When you spend 2 or more sorcery points during a turn, you can immediately use your reaction to regain 1 sorcery point.

subclassFeature.name: Soul Protection
entries: Starting at 14th level, your astral anchor protects you in response to dire threats.

Immediately after you are {@condition incapacitated} or knocked {@condition unconscious}, you can choose to gain the benefits of the {@spell Otiluke's resilient sphere|PHB|resilient sphere} spell, with the following changes: it doesn't require concentration, the sphere is resistant to all damage instead of immune, it has 15 AC, and it has 4 hit points for each of your Sorcerer levels. When all of these hit points are lost, the spell ends, and you take any remaining damage. If a creature touches the sphere, you can choose to end the spell, whether you are conscious or not. You can also choose to end it on your turn (no action required by you).
Once you have used this feature, you must finish a short or long rest before using it again.

subclassFeature.name: Astral Transport
entries: Starting at 18th level, your astral anchor has gained enough fortitude to support transporting your physical form. When you cast a spell, you can expend 3 sorcery points to teleport up to 30 feet to a point you can see before casting the spell. You also gain a short burst of power in the process, increasing the damage of the spell. The damage increase equals half your sorcerer level.

subclassFeature.name: Collective Mind
entries: You have a neural link to the central consciousness of a hive, colony, or some other collective. Those with this link have some relation to these entities; be it an integrated ancestor, indoctrination, cloning, or otherwise. Their link allows these sorcerers to use the reconnaissance and communication available to their collective.

subclassFeature.name: Origin Spells
entries: Your magic comes from the seemingly boundless knowledge and resources of your collective. You learn the following spells at the sorcerer levels listed. These spells count as sorcerer spells for you, and they do not count against your number of spells known.

subclassFeature.name: Collective Genetics
entries: When you awaken to this origin at 1st level, choose one collective from the Collective Genetics table. Your choice determines certain traits of drones you summon with your Summon Drone feature.

items.name: Speed:
entries: 30 ft. climb & 20 ft. burrow

items.name: Sense:
entries: {@sense tremorsense|MM} 60 ft.

items.name: Speed:
entries: 30 ft. fly

items.name: Keen Sight:
entries: The drone has advantage on {@skill Perception} checks requiring sight.

items.name: Sense:
entries: telepathy 120 ft., shares its host's senses

items.name: Symbiosis:
entries: The drone can't attack, and it dies if it is separated from its host for 1 minute.

items.name: Attach to Host:
entries: As an action, the drone embeds itself into a willing or {@condition unconscious} creature within 5 feet of it. While embedded, the drone is {@condition unconscious} and is indistinguishable from its host. The drone is ejected to the nearest unoccupied space if its host has 0 hit points.

items.name: Speed:
entries: 30 ft. swim

items.name: Aquatic:
entries: The drone can breathe air or water.

subclassFeature.name: Summon Drone
entries: Also at 1st level, you can summon a collective drone to an unoccupied space within 5 feet of you as an action, which lasts until it dies or you dismiss it by using your bonus action. You describe the drone's appearance, which must accommodate its features, size and traits.

data.name: Collective Drone
languages: Understands its summoner but can't speak

trait.name: Homogeneity.
entries: The attack drone gains traits based on its summoner's {@subclassFeature Collective Genetics|Variant Sorcerer|VariantSorcererByDevikyn|Collective|VariantSorcererByDevikyn|1} feature.

In combat, drones share your initiative and take the {@action Dodge} action, avoiding any danger. Drones add your proficiency bonus to their {@skill Investigation} and {@skill Perception} checks. You can use your action to see and hear through a drone's senses as long as you are on the same plane, or to return from using the drone's senses to yours.
You can have a number of drones at a time equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of 1).

subclassFeature.name: Consult Collective
entries: Starting at 6th level, you can spend 10 minutes in commune with your collective, as long as you are on the same plane of existence to inquire about one event, object or piece of information that you know. At the DM's discretion, the collective can share its knowledge as it relates to your inquiry via a truthful reply.

subclassFeature.name: Stream of Consciousness
entries: Starting at 14th level, your consciousness becomes a permanent part of your collective, which can produce a new body for you should yours perish.
If you die, you return to life 24 hours after death. You reform within 1 mile of your place of death at a point chosen by the DM. Your equipment remains where you died, if it wasn't destroyed.

subclassFeature.name: Regal Command
entries: Starting at 18th level, the regal presence of your collective mind can be implanted into the conscious of another, weaving into their psyche and inducting them into your collective.

As an action, you can touch a non-hostile creature, which must succeed on a Charisma saving throw or regard you as family. A creature that succeeds on its saving throw becomes immune to this effect for 24 hours and is aware that you attempted to manipulate it. A {@spell greater restoration} spell ends the effect.

subclassFeature.name: Gloom-touched
entries: Gloom-touched sorcerers are those who are tainted with demonic magic. These are most commonly descendants of creatures doomed to Hades by a curse, but some may also be born by ritual, a desperate pact, or some other demonic encounter. These sorcerers have magical abilities warped in dark and deranged ways, allowing them to capture and manipulate the souls of fallen creatures. Due to their demonic nature, gloom-touched sorcerers can often be subject to scorn or even violence.

subclassFeature.name: Origin Spells
entries: Calling upon demonic magic is a simple task for you, with your hellish origin. You learn the following spells at the sorcerer levels listed. These spells count as sorcerer spells for you, and they do not count against your number of spells known.

subclassFeature.name: Soul Extraction
entries: Starting when you awaken to this origin at 1st level, you can trap a fallen soul in a state of limbo, temporarily retaining it.

You can use your action to touch a creature that died within the last minute. If the creature's challenge rating is equal to or lower than your sorcerer level, you shackle its soul; the soul takes on an insubstantial, but corporeal form, which hovers near you and follows you for up to 8 hours, after which it is freed and moves on. A soul so retained cannot be resurrected until it is freed.

When you use this feature, you can ask the soul one question. If you do, the soul must make a Charisma saving throw - using its creature statistics - against your spell save DC. On a failed save, the soul is compelled to answer truthfully with whatever detail it knew in life. Otherwise, it is free to answer as it would normally.
You can retain a limited number of souls at any given time. This number equals your Charisma modifier (minimum of 1).

subclassFeature.name: Hellish Vision
entries: Also at 1st level, you gain the ability to see through the lens of hades, a vision devoid of color and detail which inflicts apathy upon its beholder.

As a bonus action, you can begin or end your hellish vision. Hellish vision functions as {@sense darkvision}, extends to your entire range of sight, and cannot be impeded by magical darkness. You cannot see color while using hellish vision, only shades of gray.

While your hellish vision is active, a wave of apathy washes over you, imposing disadvantage on your attack rolls and ability checks. You can suspend this apathy for 1 minute by using your action to drain energy from one of your retained souls. Doing so immediately frees the soul.

subclassFeature.name: Selfish Sacrifice
entries: Starting at 6th level, you can use a fragment of a trapped soul as a seed to replenish your own vitality.

When damage reduces you to 0 hit points but doesn't outright kill you, you can use a retained soul to make a Constitution saving throw (DC 10 or half of the damage, whichever is higher). On a successful save, you are instead reduced to 1 hit point. The soul is freed whether you succeed or fail.

subclassFeature.name: Soul Attractor
entries: Starting at 14th level, you can use your magic to quickly draw the souls of others to you, even at a distance.

You can use your Soul Extraction feature at a range of 30 feet, and you can expend 1 sorcery point to use the feature as a reaction when a creature other than you is reduced to 0 hit points; if you do, you also regain hit points equal to your Charisma modifier.

subclassFeature.name: Barter Souls
entries: Starting at 18th level, you can call forth a fiend to create a contract in exchange for souls.

By spending 1 minute in concentration (as if concentrating on a spell) and choosing any number of your currently retained souls, you can call forth a fiend from its native plane. Based on the number of souls offered, a creature appears in an unoccupied space of the DM's choice within 30 feet of you. Consult the Barter Souls Summoning table to find the creatures you can summon.

The fiend remains under control of the DM at all times. It offers a contract: assistance with a single task or goal in exchange for the amount of trapped souls shown in the Barter Souls Summoning table. You describe this task or goal in up to two sentences, which the fiend uses to forge the contract and immediately receive its payment. The fiend interprets your contract in good faith, and it executes a given contract to the best of its ability; however, it does not treat you as an ally for purposes beyond the calling of its contract, and its contractual obligations end if you die.

The fiend is likely to look for ways it can extract further compensation from you, and is capable of offering further deals. Once its contracts are fulfilled, or if the fiend is reduced to 0 hit points, it returns to its place of origin.

subclassFeature.name: Gravitational Magic
entries: You have the ability to sense and interact with the gravitational forces inherent in reality around you. Your magic allows you to manipulate these physics, but also confuses your psyche; a result of interacting with the natural forces of the world in ways your body and mind cannot properly decipher.

subclassFeature.name: Origin Spells
entries: Your natural control of gravity allows you to harness your magic's unique properties into easily manifested forms. You learn the following spells at the sorcerer levels listed. These spells count as sorcerer spells for you, and they do not count against your number of spells known.

subclassFeature.name: Extradimensional Mark
entries: Your sorcerous origin's abilities leave lasting and sometimes unpredictable impressions on you, altering some aspects of your behavior. Choose any number of extradimensional marks below, or roll any number of {@dice (#$prompt_number:min=1, title=Enter a Number!, default=123$#)d4|d4s} to determine your marks.

rows: Air sometimes feels solid to you. It's stifling.
You can feel the blood circulating through your veins.
Pockets of altered gravity form randomly around you, causing oddities like your clothes hanging heavily, your hair floating, or randomly losing your equilibrium.
Your balance is exceptionally poor; you are clumsy and your gait is unstable.

subclassFeature.name: Gravity Well
entries: Starting when you awaken to this origin at 1st level, you can manipulate the local effects of gravity around creatures.

As a bonus action, choose a creature that you can see within 60 feet of you. An unwilling creature can make a Charisma saving throw to avoid being affected; if it succeeds, it becomes immune to this feature for 1 minute. On a failed saving throw, choose one of the following options, which affects creatures in a 5-foot radius of the target (including the target) until the end of your next turn:

items.name: Increase Gravity.
entries: Increased pressure makes everything heavier around the target, reducing each affected creature's speed by 10 feet.

items.name: Decrease Gravity.
entries: Decreasing gravitational influence around the target makes everything around it lighter, increasing each affected creature's speed by 10 feet and halving the weight of all affected creatures and objects.

You can use your bonus action on your subsequent turns to extend this feature's duration until the end of your next turn. If you use this feature again - choosing a different target or a different option - while its effect is already active, the current effect ends.

subclassFeature.name: Unfettered Domain
entries: Also at 1st level, objects and equipment that you carry, or those contained entirely within a 5-foot radius of you, weigh half of their normal weight, unless another effect halves their weight already.

subclassFeature.name: Limber Force
entries: Starting at 6th level, you become inherently able to amplify your kinetic force with magic, and you learn to create a small, localized field of dense gravity.

When you deal damage to a creature with a sorcerer spell, you can push or pull the creature up to 10 feet. You can spend sorcery points to increase the distance that the creature is pushed or pulled by 10 feet for each sorcery point spent.

Also, when you are attacked by a source within 5 feet of you, you can use your reaction to create a field of rejecting gravity, encapsulating and slowing the strike. You gain resistance to the attack's damage, and if the attacker is a creature, it must make a Strength saving throw. On a failed save, the creature cannot make attacks until the start of its next turn. Once you have used this reaction, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Sorcerous Acceleration
entries: Starting at 14th level, you can harness control of gravity when you use magic, allowing you a short burst of gravity-induced acceleration.

If you cast a spell of 1st-level or higher, you can spend 1 sorcery point to {@action Dash} or {@action Disengage} as a bonus action. When you do, any speeds you have are doubled until the start of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Crushing Influence
entries: Starting at 18th level, your mastery of gravity allows you to intensify others' gravitational pull to such a level that those around them are crushed under the pressure.

As an action, you can spend 2 sorcery points and choose a point within 60 feet of you that you can see. Until the start of your next turn, a 20-ft radius sphere of crushing gravitational force envelops the area.

Any creature contained fully within the area of this sphere that moves more than 5 feet or starts its turn there must succeed on a Strength saving throw or fall {@condition prone} and have its speed set to 0 until the start of its next turn. Once a creature succeeds on its saving throw against this effect, it is immune to the effect until the start of its next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Sanguinary Heritage
entries: You have a taste for blood. Whether this trait is hereditary, gifted, or magical in nature, you can use your magic to draw out the essence of your foes and consume it, and you have an insatiable urge to do just that. Many such sorcerers can trace their abilities back to a powerful vampire, a bloodthirsty fiend, or a curse.

subclassFeature.name: Origin Spells
entries: The intense bloodthirst in your veins manifests in the form of magical aptitude. You learn the following spells at the sorcerer levels listed. These spells count as sorcerer spells for you, and they do not count against your number of spells known.

subclassFeature.name: Lifestealer
entries: Starting when you awaken to this origin at 1st level, your life-draining magic soothes your victim and replenishes your vitality.

When you cast a sorcerer spell of 1st level or higher that deals necrotic damage, you regain hit points equal to half of the damage dealt to one of the targets, in addition to any health the spell restores.

In addition, when you deal necrotic damage to a creature with a spell, it does not feel pain from the necrotic damage, and it must succeed a Wisdom ability check against your spell save DC to discern that it has taken damage.

subclassFeature.name: Shallow Youth
entries: Also at 1st level, your magic retains an imprint of your physical state when you first awakened to it, which can be called upon by feeding.

Whenever you regain hit points by dealing necrotic damage, you can cause your physical appearance to transform such that your age appears to be the same as when you first awakened to this Sorcerous Origin. For example, wrinkles may disappear, your posture may improve, and your hair may change in color and texture. These effects last for 24 hours, at which point you revert back to your natural appearance.

subclassFeature.name: False Dependence
entries: Starting at 6th level, victims of your magic feel a temporary need to depend on you.

You can use your bonus action and spend 2 sorcery points to choose a creature within 60 feet of you that is charmed by you or who has taken damage from one of your spells this turn. That creature must succeed on a Charisma saving throw against your spell save DC or be afflicted with Dependence, a disease that causes it to have disadvantage on Wisdom and Charisma checks against you for 10 minutes. An affected creature can repeat the saving throw each minute, ending the effect on itself on a success.

subclassFeature.name: Bathe in Blood
entries: Starting at 14th level, you can draw out your own blood and mix it into your spells, rending your enemies with sharp, lacerating magic.
When you deal damage to a creature with a sorcerer spell, you can reduce your hit points by an amount no greater than your sorcerer level to deal the same amount of slashing damage to that creature.

subclassFeature.name: True Dependence
entries: Starting at 18th level, your disease's potency increases, temporarily enthralling your victims.

Any creature afflicted with Dependence treats you as a close friend for the disease's duration. It won't risk its life for you or fight for you, unless it was already inclined to do so. It grants you favors and gifts it would offer to a close friend. You know the afflicted creature's emotional state, surface thoughts, and location relative to you at all times, as long as you are on the same plane of existence.
When the disease ends, the creature doesn't know why it held you in such high regard.

subclassFeature.name: Soulknife
entries: Soulknives are initiates of an ancient technique that uses magic to awaken the mind. These sorcerers are trained to be assassins and spies, as their abilities are difficult to discern and allow them to act rapidly. With their ability to harness both magical and mental energy, they can create lethal weapons and strike with deadly precision.

subclassFeature.name: Origin Spells
entries: Your psychic awakening affords you a repertoire of spells useful for manipulating and wearing down the mind. You learn the following spells at the sorcerer levels listed. These spells count as sorcerer spells for you, and they do not count against your number of spells known.

subclassFeature.name: Martial Training
entries: At 1st level, you gain proficiency with light armor, hand crossbows, longswords, rapiers and shortswords.
Additionally, your hit point maximum increases by 1, and it increases by 1 every time you gain a level in this class.

subclassFeature.name: Soul Focus
entries: Also at 1st level, you can construct weapons out of mental energy. These weapons deal damage directly to the minds of others, and act as a conduit for your spells.

As a bonus action, you can create a weapon that flows with mental energy, a Soul Focus, in one of your free hands. This weapon takes the form of a {@item dagger|phb}, a {@item longsword|phb}, a {@item rapier|phb} or a {@item shortsword|phb} (your choice), using the same statistics as the chosen weapon except that it does psychic damage instead of its normal damage type. You can never be disarmed of your Soul Focus unless you choose to be. You can use your Soul Focus as a spellcasting focus for your sorcerer spells. If you are {@condition unconscious} or you let go of your Soul Focus on a turn, it disappears at the end of the turn.
At certain levels in this class, you gain a bonus to attack and damage rolls made using your Soul Focus: +1 at 6th level and +2 at 14th level.

subclassFeature.name: Blinkstrike
entries: Starting at 6th level, you can use mental energy to travel through a momentary rift, cutting through your foe's defense.

You can use your bonus action and spend 2 sorcery points to teleport up to 30 feet to an unoccupied space that you can see and then make one weapon attack with your Soul Focus. At 14th level, this attack deals an extra {@dice 1d8} force damage on a hit.

subclassFeature.name: Extra Attack
entries: Also at 6th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.

subclassFeature.name: Project Will
entries: Starting at 14th level, your keen mental control allows you to create magical effects by sheer force of will.
You can cast your sorcerer spells without performing verbal and somatic components while you are wielding your Soul Focus.

subclassFeature.name: Cut the Psyche
entries: Starting at 18th level, you can overload a creature's mind when you strike it, causing you to disappear from its sight.

When you hit a creature with your Soul Focus, you can spend 3 sorcery points to force the target to make a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failed save, the creature can't see or hear you by any means until the end of your next turn.

monster.name: Collective Drone
languages: Understands its summoner but can't speak

trait.name: Homogeneity.
entries: The attack drone gains traits based on its summoner's {@subclassFeature Collective Genetics|Variant Sorcerer|VariantSorcererByDevikyn|Collective|VariantSorcererByDevikyn|1} feature.

optionalfeature.name: Anchored Spell
entries: When you cast a spell that requires concentration, you can spend 2 sorcery points to cause the spell to last until the end of your next turn, without requiring concentration, even after the spell would normally end.

optionalfeature.name: Careful Spell
entries: When you cast a spell that forces other creatures to make a saving throw, you can protect some of those creatures from the spell's full force. To do so, you spend 1 sorcery point and choose a number of those creatures up to your Charisma modifier (minimum of one creature). A chosen creature automatically succeeds on its saving throw against the spell.

optionalfeature.name: Distant Spell
entries: When you cast a spell that has a range of 5 feet or greater, you can expend 1 sorcery point to double the range of the spell.
When you cast a spell that has a range of touch, you can expend 1 sorcery point to make the range of the spell 30 feet.

optionalfeature.name: Empowered Spell
entries: When you roll damage for a spell, or when you roll a pool of dice for a spell (such as with the sleep spell), you can spend 1 sorcery point to reroll a number of the damage or pooled dice up to your Charisma modifier(minimum of one). You must use the new rolls.
You can use Empowered Spell even if you have already used a different metamagic option during the casting of the spell.

optionalfeature.name: Extended Spell
entries: When you cast a spell that has a duration of 1 minute or longer, you can spend 2 sorcery points to double its duration, to a maximum duration of 24 hours.

optionalfeature.name: Fortifying Spell
entries: When you cast a spell of 1st level or higher, you can spend sorcery points equal to the spell's level to roll the same number of d4s and gain temporary hit points equal to the total amount rolled.

optionalfeature.name: Heightened Spell
entries: When a spell of yours requires one or more targets to make a saving throw to resist the spell's effects, you can use your reaction and expend 3 sorcery points to give one target of the spell disadvantage on its saving throw.

optionalfeature.name: Homing Spell
entries: When you make a ranged attack roll for a spell you cast, you can spend 2 sorcery points to reroll the attack once and use the second result. You can use this metamagic after the attack roll, but before the DM determines whether the attack hits.
You can use Homing Spell even if you have already used a different metamagic option during the casting of the spell.

optionalfeature.name: Lashing Spell
entries: When you cast a spell that has an area of effect and a duration of instantaneous, you can spend 2 sorcery points to create a whirl containing the spell's effect. When you do, the spell's area remains until the end of your next turn, affecting each creature who enters the area for the first time on a turn or ends its turn within the area.

optionalfeature.name: Miring Spell
entries: When you cast a spell with an area of effect, you can expend 2 sorcery points to create a lingering field of force. The spell's area of effect becomes difficult terrain until the start of your next turn.

optionalfeature.name: Persistent Spell
entries: When a spell ends before its full duration has elapsed, you can use your reaction and spend sorcery points equal to 1 + half the spell's level (rounded down) to choose a different target for the spell instead of ending it. The target you choose must be one that you can see, one suitable to the spell and within 30 feet of the original target.

optionalfeature.name: Prismatic Spell
entries: When you cast a spell that deals acid, cold, fire, lightning, or poison damage, you can spend 1 sorcery point to change one such damage type to another from the same list.

entries.name: Variant Sorcerer
entries: The {@i {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|DMG}} contains a variant rule for {@variantrule spell points}, an alternative to spell slots that draws your magical power from a pool rather than using slots to cast spells. This rule is controversial for most spellcasters, as it grants a large pool of low level spells without much justification. Sorcerers, however, have the Font of Magic feature, which allows them to interchange spell slots and sorcery points. This creates a dynamic that closely emulates spell points without actually using them.

Using this concept as a baseline, I've created a variant of the sorcerer which has a modified version of the spell points rule and adds some new features. Its purpose is to allow use of spell points with less of the abuse of low level spells granted by spell points at later character levels.

entries.name: Spells Known & Metamagic
entries: Another issue that sorcerers have is their lack of spells known, and the "metagame" of their metamagic options. To this end, I've modified the Font of Magic feature to allow short bursts of powerful casting, and I've given each origin an additional known spell of levels 1-5. For the remaining Metamagic, I've given new options, more frequent and consistent intervals at which the sorcerer learns metamagic, and allowed you to swap metamagic choices when you gain a new one.

entries.name: Spell Points
entries: This sorcerer uses a modified version of the DMG's {@variantrule spell points|DMG|spell point} rule, which has been simplified. It also incorporates a more powerful version of the Warlock's {@classFeature Mystic Arcanum (6th level)|Warlock||11||Mystic Arcanum} feature. This combination helps to round out the issues with sorcery points at later levels by reducing the sorcery point pool.

Particularly, the overwhelming amount of low-level spells you can cast at player levels beyond 10 is replaced with powerful high-level spellcasting. The intent of these changes is to make the sorcerer a much more varied caster, and to make it as spontaneous as I feel comfortable with in 5th edition.

entries.name: Boosting the Capstone
entries: The sorcerer's {@classFeature Sorcerous Restoration|Sorcerer||20||level 20 feature} is not terribly weak, but it's underwhelming for the level at which you get it. {@classFeature Arcane Recovery|Wizard||1||Wizards} and {@subclassFeature Natural Recovery|Druid||Land||2||Land Druids} can regain spell slots starting at level 2, and it scales throughout their career. Sorcerers get metamagic instead, but as a class that is driven by their spellcasting capabilities, they deserved to have something similar, so I moved it to level 3 and made it scale with your level. I added a new capstone to replace it: a feature that truly makes you a master of flexing your spellcasting. It's powerful, but fun for such high levels.

entries.name: Sorcerer
entries: Golden eyes flashing, a human stretches out her hand and unleashes the dragonfire that burns in her veins. As an inferno rages around her foes, leathery wings spread from her back and she takes to the air.

Long hair whipped by a conjured wind, a half-elf spreads his arms wide and throws his head back. Lifting him momentarily off the ground, a wave of magic surges up in him, through him, and out from him in a mighty blast of lightning.

Crouching behind a stalagmite, a halfling points a finger at a charging troglodyte. A blast of fire springs from her finger to strike the creature. She ducks back behind the rock formation with a grin, unaware that her wild magic has turned her skin bright blue.

Sorcerers carry a magical birthright conferred upon them by an exotic bloodline, some otherworldly influence, or exposure to unknown cosmic forces. One can't study sorcery as one learns a language, any more than one can learn to live a legendary life. No one chooses sorcery; the power chooses the sorcerer.

entries.name: Raw Magic
entries: Magic is a part of every sorcerer, suffusing body, mind, and spirit with a latent power that waits to be tapped. Some sorcerers wield magic that springs from an ancient bloodline infused with the magic of dragons. Others carry a raw, uncontrolled magic within them, a chaotic storm that manifests in unexpected ways.

The appearance of sorcerous powers is wildly unpredictable. Some draconic bloodlines produce exactly one sorcerer in every generation, but in other lines of descent every individual is a sorcerer. Most of the time, the talents of sorcery appear as apparent flukes. Some sorcerers can't name the origin of their power, while others trace it to strange events in their own lives. The touch of a demon, the blessing of a dryad at a baby's birth, or a taste of the water from a mysterious spring might spark the gift of sorcery. So too might the gift of a deity of magic, exposure to the elemental forces of the Inner Planes or the maddening chaos of Limbo, or a glimpse into the inner workings of reality.

Sorcerers have no use for the spellbooks and ancient tomes of magic lore that wizards rely on, nor do they rely on a patron to grant their spells as warlocks do. By learning to harness and channel their own inborn magic, they can discover new and staggering ways to unleash that power.

entries.name: Unexplained Powers
entries: Sorcerers are rare in the world, and it's unusual to find a sorcerer who is not involved in the adventuring life in some way. People with magical power seething in their veins soon discover that the power doesn't like to stay quiet. A sorcerer's magic wants to be wielded, and it has a tendency to spill out in unpredictable ways if it isn't called on.

Sorcerers often have obscure or quixotic motivations driving them to adventure. Some seek a greater understanding of the magical force that infuses them, or the answer to the mystery of its origin. Others hope to find a way to get rid of it, or to unleash its full potential. Whatever their goals, sorcerers are every bit as useful to an adventuring party as wizards, making up for a comparative lack of breadth in their magical knowledge with enormous flexibility in using the spells they know.

entries.name: Creating a Sorcerer
entries: The most important question to consider when creating your sorcerer is the origin of your power. As a starting character, you'll choose an origin that ties to a draconic bloodline or the influence of wild magic, but the exact source of your power is up to you to decide. Is it a family curse, passed down to you from distant ancestors? Or did some extraordinary event leave you blessed with inherent magic but perhaps scarred as well?

How do you feel about the magical power coursing through you? Do you embrace it, try to master it, or revel in its unpredictable nature? Is it a blessing or a curse? Did you seek it out, or did it find you? Did you have the option to refuse it, and do you wish you had? What do you intend to do with it? Perhaps you feel like you've been given this power for some lofty purpose. Or you might decide that the power gives you the right to do what you want, to take what you want from those who lack such power. Perhaps your power links you to a powerful individual in the world—the fey creature that blessed you at birth, the dragon who put a drop of its blood into your veins, the lich who created you as an experiment, or the deity who chose you to carry this power.

entries.name: Quick Build
entries: You can make a sorcerer quickly by following these suggestions. First, Charisma should be your highest ability score, followed by Constitution. Second, choose the hermit background. Third, choose the {@spell light}, {@spell prestidigitation}, {@spell ray of frost}, and {@spell shocking grasp} cantrips, along with the 1st-level spells {@spell shield} and {@spell magic missile}.
Practice and study are for amateurs. True power is a birthright.

When it comes to drawing forth their abilities in times of need, sorcerers have it easy compared to other characters. Their power not only rests within them, but it likely takes some effort to keep it at bay. Every sorcerer is born to the role, or stumbles into it through cosmic chance. Unlike other characters, who must actively learn, embrace, and pursue their talents, sorcerers have their power thrust upon them.

Because the idea of an innately magical being traveling among them does not sit well with many folk, sorcerers tend to breed mistrust and suspicion in others they come across. Nonetheless, many sorcerers succeed in overcoming that prejudice through deeds that benefit their less magically gifted contemporaries.

Sorcerers are often defined by the events surrounding the manifestation of their power. For those who receive it as an expected birthright, its appearance is a cause for celebration. Other sorcerers are treated as outcasts, banished from their homes after the sudden, terrifying arrival of their abilities.
Playing a sorcerer character can be as rewarding as it is challenging. The sections below offer suggestions on how to flesh out and personalize your persona.

entries.name: Arcane Origins
entries: Some sorcerers understand where their power came from, based on how their abilities manifested. Others can only speculate, since their powers came to them in a way that suggests no particular cause.

Does your character know the source of your magical power? Does it tie back to some distant relative, a cosmic event, or blind chance? If your sorcerer doesn't know where their power arose from, your DM can use this table (or select an origin) and reveal it to you when the information plays a role in the campaign.

entries.caption: Arcane Origins
rows: Your power arises from your family's bloodline. You are related to some powerful creature, or you inherited a blessing or a curse.
You are the reincarnation of a being from another plane of existence.
A powerful entity entered the world. Its magic changed you.
Your birth was prophesied in an ancient text, and you are foretold to use your power for terrible ends.
You are the product of generations of careful, selective breeding.
You were made in a vat by an alchemist.

entries.name: Reaction
entries: When a new sorcerer enters the world, either at birth or later when one's power becomes evident, the consequences of that event depend greatly on how its witnesses react to what they have seen.
When your sorcerer's powers appeared, how did the world around you respond? Were other people supportive, fearful, or somewhere in between?

entries.caption: Reactions
rows: Your powers are seen as a great blessing by those around you, and you are expected to use them in service to your community.
Your powers caused destruction and even a death when they became evident, and you were treated as a criminal.
Your neighbors hate and fear your power, causing them to shun you.
You came to the attention of a sinister cult that plans on exploiting your abilities.
People around you believe that your powers are a curse levied on your family for a past transgression.
Your powers are believed to be tied to an ancient line of mad kings that supposedly ended in a bloody revolt over a century ago.

entries.name: Supernatural Mark
entries: A sorcerer at rest is almost indistinguishable from a normal person; it's only when their magic flies forth that sorcerers reveal their true nature. Even so, many sorcerers have a subtle but telling physical trait that sets them apart from other folk.
If your sorcerer has a supernatural mark, it might be one that's easily concealed, or it could be a source of pride that you keep on constant display.

entries.caption: Supernatural Marks
rows: Your eyes are an unusual color, such as red.
You have an extra toe on one foot.
One of your ears is noticeably larger than the other.
Your hair grows at a prodigious rate.
You wrinkle your nose repeatedly while you are chewing.
A red splotch appears on your neck once a day, then vanishes after an hour.

entries.name: Signs of Sorcery
entries: As the world well knows, some sorcerers are better than others at controlling their spellcasting. Sometimes a wild display of magic gone awry emanates from a sorcerer who casts a spell. But even when one's magic goes off as planned, the act of casting is often accompanied by a telltale sign that makes it clear where that magical energy came from.

When your sorcerer character casts a spell, does the effort reveal itself in a sign of sorcery? Is this sign tied to your origin or some other aspect of who you are, or is it a seemingly random phenomenon?

entries.caption: Signs of Sorcery
rows: You deliver the verbal components of your spells in the booming voice of a titan.
For a moment after you cast a spell, the area around you grows dark and gloomy.
You sweat profusely while casting a spell and for a few seconds thereafter.
Your hair and garments are briefly buffeted about, as if by a breeze, whenever you call forth a spell.
If you are standing when you cast a spell, you rise six inches into the air and gently float back down.
Illusory blue flames wreathe your head as you begin your casting, then abruptly disappear.
